Award.AwardTitle: Perturbative QCD Study for Jet and Heavy Flavor Production
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Zhongbo Kang at the University of California, Los Angeles.

After nearly twenty years of planning and construction, the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is now the highest-energy particle collider in the world. By colliding elementary particles against each other at high energies, physicists expect to learn about the fundamental building blocks of matter and their interactions at higher energies and smaller distances than have ever been previously explored. Collimated jets of hadrons are a dominant feature of high-energy particle interactions, and are copiously produced at the LHC. The research of Professor Kang is focused on understanding the production of these strongly interacting particles, from which important information can be extracted. Jets constitute unique opportunities to explore the dynamics of the strong interaction and to study the fundamental properties of the underlying theory, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). As a result, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions: the discovery and understanding of new physical law. This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts. Professor Kang will involve graduate students in his research, and thereby provide critical training for junior physicists beginning research in this field. He also intends to give public lectures on his research results, and develop new course curricula based on results from the LHC.

More technically, Professor Kang will develop theoretical tools to perform accurate QCD phenomenology at the LHC, especially for inclusive and heavy flavor tagged jets and their substructure. He will also perform studies for heavy quarkonium production by making use of a novel fragmentation function approach within QCD factorization. In addition, he will combine the frameworks of heavy quarkonium physics and jet substructure in order to achieve a better understanding of the production and polarization of heavy quarkonium at the LHC, which is currently one of the most intriguing puzzles in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the highest energy collider in the world - Large Hadron Collider, collimated spray of particles, commonly referred to as jets, are abundantly produced. These jets are interesting as tests of the fundamental theory of strong interactions - Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), as well as forming important backgrounds for Standard Model (SM) and beyond. In addition, the internal structure of jets, or jet substructure, has emerged as a powerful tool for identifying jets originating from the decay of highly-Lorentz-boosted SM particles.

This project has developed important theoretical frames and computational tools to advance the jet cross sections, and to study various types of jet substructure observables (jet mass, jet shape, jet angularity, and groomed jet radius) from the first principle of QCD. The theoretical calculations are compared with the experimental measurements from the LHC and have shown good agreements. The developed framework of exploring distribution of particles (such as heavy quarkonium) inside the jet enables us to understand the elusive hadronization process, i.e., how fundamental degrees of freedom of QCD (quarks and gluons) convert themselves back to the hadrons. The project have eventually resulted in 16 papers in peer-reviewed journals such as Physics Letters B, Journal of High Energy Physics, and Physical Review D. Among these papers, 5 of them were published as letters: 1 in Physical Review Letters, 1 as a letter in Physical Review D, and 3 in Physics Letters B. At the same time, the PI and his team have delivered 23 talks via seminars and presentations at international and national conferences and workshops. 

We have involved postdoctoral scholars, graduate and undergraduate students in our research and thereby provided critical training for junior physicists beginning research in this field. One graduate student has received Nina Byers Summer Fellowship in Theoretical Physics from UCLA Bhaumik Institute for Theoretical Physics for the work performed in this project. The PI also received a Merit Award from Brookhaven National Laboratory, and half of the citation was based on jet physics developed through the support of this award. In addition, one postdoc has moved on to a faculty position. Finally, the research topics have also been implemented in an outreach event to show the simulations of particle collisions at high energies.
